title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 9 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Corinthians chapter 9 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 9 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Corinthians Chapter 9.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 9:1, what question does Paul ask about his apostleship?
options: Have I not worked in the Lord?
questions.correctAnswer: Am I not an apostle?
questions.explanation: Paul asks 'Am I not an apostle?' to assert his authority (1 Corinthians 9:1).

questions.question: Who does Paul say are the seal of his apostleship in 1 Corinthians 9:2?
questions.correctAnswer: The Corinthians
questions.explanation: Paul states that the Corinthians are the seal of his apostleship (1 Corinthians 9:2).

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 9:4, Paul asks if they do not have power to eat and to drink.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Paul asks, 'Have we not power to eat and to drink?' (1 Corinthians 9:4).

questions.question: What example does Paul use in 1 Corinthians 9:7 to illustrate that those who work deserve to benefit?
options: Who planteth a vineyard and eateth not of the fruit?
Who builds a house and lives in it?
Who teaches the law and is honored?
Who sails a ship and receives wages?
questions.correctAnswer: Who planteth a vineyard and eateth not of the fruit?
questions.explanation: Paul uses the example of planting a vineyard and eating of its fruit to show workers deserve their benefit (1 Corinthians 9:7).

questions.question: Fill in the blank from 1 Corinthians 9:9: 'Thou shalt not muzzle the mouth of the ______ that treadeth out the corn.'
questions.correctAnswer: ox
questions.explanation: The verse specifically mentions 'the ox that treadeth out the corn' (1 Corinthians 9:9).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 9:11, if Paul and others have sown spiritual things, what is it a great thing to reap?
questions.correctAnswer: Your carnal things
questions.explanation: Paul says if they have sown unto you spiritual things, is it a great thing if they shall reap your carnal things (1 Corinthians 9:11).

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 9:12, Paul and his companions have used their power to demand support.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Paul says they have not used their power to demand support, but suffer all things to not hinder the gospel (1 Corinthians 9:12).

questions.question: What does Paul say those who minister about holy things live of, according to 1 Corinthians 9:13?
questions.correctAnswer: The things of the temple
questions.explanation: Paul mentions that those who minister about holy things live of the things of the temple (1 Corinthians 9:13).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 9:14, who ordained that those who preach the gospel should live of the gospel?
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord
questions.explanation: Paul states that the Lord has ordained that those who preach the gospel should live of the gospel (1 Corinthians 9:14).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 9:15, what would Paul rather do than have anyone make his glorying void?
questions.correctAnswer: Die
questions.explanation: Paul says it would be better for him to die than that any man should make his glorying void (1 Corinthians 9:15).

questions.question: True or False: In 1 Corinthians 9:16, Paul says he has much to glory in when preaching the gospel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Paul says he has nothing to glory in because necessity is laid upon him, and woe is unto him if he does not preach (1 Corinthians 9:16).

questions.question: What is Paul's reward when he preaches the gospel willingly, according to 1 Corinthians 9:17?
questions.correctAnswer: A reward
questions.explanation: Paul states that if he preaches willingly, he has a reward (1 Corinthians 9:17).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 9:19, although Paul is free from all men, what has he made himself?
questions.correctAnswer: A servant unto all
questions.explanation: Paul says he has made himself a servant unto all to gain the more (1 Corinthians 9:19).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 9:24, what comparison does Paul use to encourage believers to run so as to obtain the prize?
options: They which run in a race
questions.correctAnswer: They which run in a race
questions.explanation: Paul compares believers to runners in a race to encourage them to strive for the prize (1 Corinthians 9:24).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 9:27, why does Paul keep under his body and bring it into subjection?
options: Lest he himself should be a castaway
questions.correctAnswer: Lest he himself should be a castaway
questions.explanation: Paul disciplines himself so that after preaching to others he himself is not disqualified or a castaway (1 Corinthians 9:27).

medium.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 9 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Corinthians Chapter 9 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 9 teach us about the importance of perseverance in ministry despite personal sacrifice?
options: Paul chooses to endure hardships to avoid hindering the gospel
Paul insists on receiving full payment for his work
Paul avoids ministry when it becomes difficult
Paul delegates all difficult tasks to others
questions.correctAnswer: Paul chooses to endure hardships to avoid hindering the gospel
questions.explanation: In 1 Corinthians 9:12, Paul explains that he suffers all things so as not to hinder the gospel of Christ, showing the importance of perseverance despite sacrifice. This is supported by verses 15-16 where he says it would be better for him to die than to make his glorying void and that necessity is laid upon him to preach.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 9, what principle does Paul use to illustrate the right of a minister to receive support?
options: An ox is not muzzled while treading out the corn
A farmer plants but does not eat fruit
A shepherd feeds the flock but receives no milk
questions.correctAnswer: An ox is not muzzled while treading out the corn
questions.explanation: Paul refers to the law of Moses in 1 Corinthians 9:9, stating 'Thou shalt not muzzle the mouth of the ox that treadeth out the corn,' to illustrate that those who labor in ministry deserve to be supported. This is further emphasized in verses 7-10.

questions.question: What attitude towards freedom and service does Paul demonstrate in 1 Corinthians 9?
options: Though free, he becomes servant to all to win more people
He asserts his freedom and refuses to adapt to others
He demands others serve him because he is free
He isolates himself to maintain personal freedom
questions.correctAnswer: Though free, he becomes servant to all to win more people
questions.explanation: In verse 19, Paul explains that although he is free from all men, he has made himself a servant to all to gain more, exemplifying humility and self-sacrifice for evangelism. This is echoed in verses 20-22 where he adapts to different groups for their sake.

questions.question: A believer struggles with balancing self-discipline and Christian freedom. Based on 1 Corinthians 9, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Discipline your body to avoid being disqualified
Use your freedom without any restraint
Avoid self-control to enjoy life fully
Focus only on spiritual matters, ignoring the body
questions.correctAnswer: Discipline your body to avoid being disqualified
questions.explanation: Paul teaches in verse 27 that he disciplines his body and brings it into subjection to avoid being disqualified after preaching to others. This highlights the need for self-control in the Christian walk, supported by verses 24-26 about running the race with purpose and temperance.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 9 encourage believers to view their efforts in evangelism?
options: Be willing to adapt and become 'all things to all men' to save some
Only evangelize those exactly like yourself
Demand others change before sharing the gospel
questions.correctAnswer: Be willing to adapt and become 'all things to all men' to save some
questions.explanation: Verses 20-22 show Paul's strategy of adapting to different cultural and legal contexts to win others to Christ. He becomes like Jews, those under the law, or without law to reach as many as possible, demonstrating practical evangelism.

questions.question: What does Paul say about boasting in his gospel work in 1 Corinthians 9?
options: He has nothing to boast of except the necessity to preach
He boasts of his miraculous signs
He boasts of his social status
He boasts about his financial gain
questions.correctAnswer: He has nothing to boast of except the necessity to preach
questions.explanation: In verse 16, Paul states he has no cause to glory except that necessity is laid upon him to preach the gospel, emphasizing humility and the weight of responsibility in ministry.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 9, Paul insists on exercising his right to receive financial support from the churches.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Paul acknowledges his right to financial support (verses 4-14) but chooses not to use this right so as not to hinder the gospel (verse 12). He preaches without charge (verse 18).

questions.question: What motivation does Paul express for running the Christian race, as found in 1 Corinthians 9?
options: To please people rather than God
questions.correctAnswer: To obtain an incorruptible crown
questions.explanation: Verse 25 contrasts earthly athletes who strive for a corruptible crown with believers who strive for an incorruptible crown, showing that Paul's motivation is eternal reward.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to 1 Corinthians 9:14, the Lord ordained that those who preach the gospel should _________.
questions.correctAnswer: live of the gospel
questions.explanation: Verse 14 states, 'Even so hath the Lord ordained that they which preach the gospel should live of the gospel,' indicating that gospel ministers have a right to material support.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 9, how does Paul describe his approach to winning those under the law?
options: He becomes as under the law to gain those under the law
He condemns those under the law
He insists they abandon the law first
questions.correctAnswer: He becomes as under the law to gain those under the law
questions.explanation: Verse 20-21 explain that Paul becomes as one under the law, though not under the law to God but under Christ, to win those under the law.

questions.question: True or False: Paul compares the Christian life to a race and urges believers to run so they may obtain the prize.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In verse 24, Paul explicitly compares the Christian life to a race where all run but only one receives the prize, encouraging believers to run to obtain it.

questions.question: Based on 1 Corinthians 9, what biblical truth would you share with someone struggling with pride in ministry?
options: True glory comes from faithfully preaching, not from personal boasting
Boasting is necessary to gain respect
Ministers should seek honor above all
Personal achievement is the key to ministry success
questions.correctAnswer: True glory comes from faithfully preaching, not from personal boasting
questions.explanation: Paul says in verses 15-16 that he does not boast except in his necessity to preach the gospel, indicating that true glory is in faithful ministry, not self-exaltation.

questions.question: What example does Paul use to teach about working and enjoying the fruit of labor in 1 Corinthians 9?
options: A soldier does not fight at his own expense
A farmer plants but never eats the fruit
questions.correctAnswer: A soldier does not fight at his own expense
questions.explanation: In verse 7, Paul asks rhetorical questions, including 'Who goeth a warfare any time at his own charges?' illustrating that those who labor deserve support.

questions.question: How does Paul illustrate his sense of obligation to preach the gospel in 1 Corinthians 9?
options: He says woe is unto him if he does not preach
He relies on others to preach
questions.correctAnswer: He says woe is unto him if he does not preach
questions.explanation: In verse 16, Paul states that necessity is laid upon him and that woe is unto him if he does not preach the gospel, showing his deep sense of responsibility.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 9, how should believers view self-control in their Christian walk?
options: Self-control is necessary to run the race effectively
Freedom means no restraint is needed
questions.correctAnswer: Self-control is necessary to run the race effectively
questions.explanation: Verses 24-27 emphasize temperance and disciplining the body to avoid disqualification, teaching the importance of self-control for all believers.

hard.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 9 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Corinthians Chapter 9.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 9:9, Paul cites the law of Moses stating, 'Thou shalt not muzzle the mouth of the ox that treadeth out the corn.' What is the primary typological significance of this Old Testament law in the context of Paul's argument?
options: It illustrates the principle that laborers deserve to benefit from their work
It commands ethical treatment of animals in agricultural practices
It emphasizes animal sacrifice laws in the Mosaic covenant
It symbolizes the purity required for temple service
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates the principle that laborers deserve to benefit from their work
questions.explanation: In 1 Corinthians 9:9, Paul uses this law to typologically demonstrate that those who work, including ministers of the gospel, should be supported by the fruits of their labor.

questions.question: Which rhetorical device does Paul employ in 1 Corinthians 9:7 when he asks, 'Who goeth a warfare any time at his own charges? who planteth a vineyard, and eateth not of the fruit thereof?'?
options: Rhetorical questions to emphasize legitimate rights
questions.correctAnswer: Rhetorical questions to emphasize legitimate rights
questions.explanation: Paul uses rhetorical questions in verse 7 to underscore the natural expectation that workers should be supported, reinforcing his argument about apostles' rights.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 9:16, Paul says, 'For though I preach the gospel, I have nothing to glory of: for necessity is laid upon me; yea, woe is unto me, if I preach not the gospel!' What Greek term underlies the concept of 'necessity' here and how does it inform Paul's sense of duty?
questions.correctAnswer: Anankē (ἀνάγκη), indicating an irresistible compulsion
questions.explanation: Paul uses the Greek term 'anankē' in 1 Corinthians 9:16, emphasizing a divine compulsion or necessity that drives him to preach the gospel, underscoring his profound sense of obligation.

questions.question: How does Paul's self-description in 1 Corinthians 9:19, 'For though I be free from all men, yet have I made myself servant unto all,' exemplify the theme of kenosis found elsewhere in Scripture?
options: It parallels Christ's self-emptying described in Philippians 2
It contradicts the concept of divine sovereignty
It highlights Paul’s social status as an apostle
It prefigures the Old Testament servant songs
questions.correctAnswer: It parallels Christ's self-emptying described in Philippians 2
questions.explanation: Paul’s voluntary self-limitation and service to others in 1 Corinthians 9:19 reflects the kenosis (self-emptying) of Christ described in Philippians 2, emphasizing humility and sacrifice for the gospel.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 9:24-25, Paul uses athletic imagery to exhort believers. What is the theological significance of contrasting a 'corruptible crown' with an 'incorruptible' one?
options: It differentiates temporal earthly rewards from eternal divine rewards
It contrasts pagan and Christian ideals of victory
It distinguishes between physical fitness and spiritual discipline
It symbolizes victory in war versus peace
questions.correctAnswer: It differentiates temporal earthly rewards from eternal divine rewards
questions.explanation: Paul contrasts the temporary nature of human accolades with the eternal, incorruptible reward of salvation, encouraging believers to pursue spiritual discipline for everlasting gain.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 9:14, what precedent does Paul cite to justify that those who preach the gospel should 'live of the gospel'?
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord's own ordinance
questions.explanation: Paul states in 1 Corinthians 9:14 that it is ordained by the Lord that those who preach the gospel should be supported by it, affirming divine approval for ministerial support.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 9:20, Paul adapts his behavior to different groups. What is the primary purpose of this adaptability according to verse 22?
options: That he might gain some by all means
To conform to cultural norms for respectability
To demonstrate his own freedom in Christ
questions.correctAnswer: That he might gain some by all means
questions.explanation: Paul’s adaptability in verse 22 is a strategic evangelistic approach to reach diverse people, aiming to save some through cultural sensitivity and self-sacrifice.

questions.question: What is the significance of Paul's statement in 1 Corinthians 9:27 about keeping his body under and bringing it into subjection in light of ancient athletic practices?
options: It reflects the discipline of athletes who exercise self-control to win a prize
It symbolizes ritual purity required for temple service
It represents fasting practices among first-century Christians
It is an allegory for mortifying the flesh as taught by John the Baptist
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the discipline of athletes who exercise self-control to win a prize
questions.explanation: Paul uses the metaphor of athletic discipline in 1 Corinthians 9:27, emphasizing self-control to avoid disqualification, paralleling the strict training of athletes in Greco-Roman culture.

questions.question: True or False: In 1 Corinthians 9:12, Paul admits to exercising his right to financial support to avoid hindering the gospel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Paul explicitly states in 1 Corinthians 9:12 that although he has the right to financial support, he has chosen not to exercise it to avoid hindering the gospel.

questions.question: What literary structure is evident in Paul's contrasting of his roles 'to the Jews, as a Jew,' and 'to them that are without law, as without law' in 1 Corinthians 9:20-21?
options: Parallelism illustrating his adaptive ministry strategy
Chiasmus emphasizing the centrality of the gospel
Allegory representing the Old and New Covenants
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism illustrating his adaptive ministry strategy
questions.explanation: Paul uses parallelism in verses 20-21 to demonstrate his cultural adaptability in ministry, showing a balanced and deliberate approach to evangelism.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 9:13, Paul refers to those who minister about holy things living from the things of the temple. This is an allusion to which Old Testament practice?
options: The Levitical priests receiving tithes and offerings
questions.correctAnswer: The Levitical priests receiving tithes and offerings
questions.explanation: Paul alludes to the Old Testament practice where Levitical priests lived off temple offerings, supporting his argument for gospel ministers to be supported similarly.

questions.question: Which theme prevalent in 1 Corinthians 9 is also a significant motif in the book of Philippians, particularly in chapter 2?
questions.correctAnswer: Self-sacrificial service and humility
questions.explanation: The theme of self-sacrificial service and humility in 1 Corinthians 9:19 aligns with the kenosis hymn in Philippians 2, reflecting Christlike humility and servant leadership.

questions.question: Paul’s assertion in 1 Corinthians 9:11, 'If we have sown unto you spiritual things, is it a great thing if we shall reap your carnal things?' employs agricultural metaphor. What biblical principle does this metaphor primarily convey?
options: The principle of reciprocal benefit in ministry
The separation of spiritual and bodily needs
The importance of soil preparation for growth
questions.correctAnswer: The principle of reciprocal benefit in ministry
questions.explanation: Paul’s metaphor in 1 Corinthians 9:11 emphasizes that just as a farmer expects to reap what he sows, ministers have a right to receive material support in return for spiritual labor.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 9:15, Paul states he would rather die than have his glorying made void. What does this reveal about the nature of his apostleship and mission?
options: His apostolic authority is non-negotiable and central to his identity
He seeks personal fame above all else
His mission is to overthrow Jewish law
He desires to be free from all earthly obligations
questions.correctAnswer: His apostolic authority is non-negotiable and central to his identity
questions.explanation: Paul’s strong statement in 1 Corinthians 9:15 shows that his role and glorying as an apostle are essential and that he would endure even death rather than lose that divine commission.

questions.question: What is the cultural significance of Paul's mention of 'a sister, a wife' in 1 Corinthians 9:5 regarding the rights of apostles?
options: It highlights the accepted cultural practice of apostles having traveling companions or spouses
It indicates celibacy was mandatory for ministry
It refers to adoption customs in the early church
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights the accepted cultural practice of apostles having traveling companions or spouses
questions.explanation: Paul’s reference in 1 Corinthians 9:5 shows that apostles like Peter (Cephas) had wives who accompanied them, affirming cultural norms and apostles’ rights to marital support.

theological.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 9 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Corinthians Chapter 9 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is Paul’s primary argument for his apostleship in 1 Corinthians 9?
options: He has seen Jesus Christ our Lord
questions.correctAnswer: He has seen Jesus Christ our Lord
questions.explanation: Paul argues for his apostleship by asserting he has seen Jesus Christ our Lord, establishing his authority based on a direct encounter with the risen Christ (1 Corinthians 9:1). This is consistent with Acts 9:1-19 where Paul’s conversion is described, and also aligns with John 20:24-29 where apostolic authority is linked to witnessing the risen Christ.

questions.question: According to Paul in 1 Corinthians 9, what right do apostles have concerning their living and support?
options: To eat and drink from their ministry
To own property in the church
questions.correctAnswer: To eat and drink from their ministry
questions.explanation: Paul asserts that apostles have the right to eat and drink from their ministry (1 Corinthians 9:4), paralleling Old Testament laws such as Deuteronomy 25:4 and Numbers 18:8-32 where those serving in holy duties receive material support, and Jesus’ teaching in Luke 10:7 that the laborer is worthy of his wages.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 9:5, Paul refers to 'leading about a sister, a wife.' To whom is he comparing this practice?
options: Other apostles and the brethren of the Lord, and Cephas
questions.correctAnswer: Other apostles and the brethren of the Lord, and Cephas
questions.explanation: Paul mentions that having a wife who accompanies him is a right shared by other apostles, the brethren of the Lord, and Cephas (Peter), indicating that this practice was normative among early leaders (1 Corinthians 9:5). This reflects the human realities of apostleship, consistent with references to Peter’s wife in Matthew 8:14 and early church leadership patterns in Acts 1:14.

questions.question: How does Paul justify the apostles’ right to material support using the Old Testament law?
options: By citing the law that an ox should not be muzzled while treading out the grain
By referring to the law of sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: By citing the law that an ox should not be muzzled while treading out the grain
questions.explanation: Paul appeals to Deuteronomy 25:4 which commands that an ox should not be muzzled while treading out the grain, symbolizing that workers deserve to benefit from their labor. This law undergirds his argument that ministers of the gospel should receive material support (1 Corinthians 9:9). This principle is reaffirmed in Luke 10:7 and 1 Timothy 5:18.

questions.question: What motivation does Paul give for sometimes foregoing his rights to support as an apostle?
options: To avoid hindering the gospel of Christ
questions.correctAnswer: To avoid hindering the gospel of Christ
questions.explanation: Paul willingly refrains from exercising his rights to financial support so as not to hinder the spread of the gospel (1 Corinthians 9:12). This self-denial aligns with Jesus’ teaching on servanthood (Mark 10:45) and Paul’s example of becoming all things to all people (1 Corinthians 9:22) to win some for Christ.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 9:14, what has the Lord ordained for those who preach the gospel?
options: That they should live of the gospel
questions.correctAnswer: That they should live of the gospel
questions.explanation: Paul teaches that the Lord has ordained that those who preach the gospel should live from the gospel, meaning they are entitled to material support from their ministry (1 Corinthians 9:14). This reflects the principle in Numbers 18:20-24 regarding the Levites and the support of temple workers, and echoes Jesus’ affirmation in Luke 10:7.

questions.question: Why does Paul say he has not claimed his rights to material support as an apostle?
options: He preferred to avoid anyone making his glorying void
He was not interested in money
He was not allowed by the church
questions.correctAnswer: He preferred to avoid anyone making his glorying void
questions.explanation: Paul states that he has not made use of his rights because he would rather die than let anyone nullify his boast or glorying (1 Corinthians 9:15). His motivation is to maintain the integrity and purity of his ministry, consistent with his teaching in 2 Corinthians 11:12-15 about guarding the gospel.

questions.question: What does Paul say about preaching the gospel if he does not do it?
options: Woe is unto me if I preach not the gospel
It is not necessary for him
questions.correctAnswer: Woe is unto me if I preach not the gospel
questions.explanation: Paul emphasizes the necessity and compulsion to preach the gospel, declaring 'woe is unto me if I preach not the gospel' (1 Corinthians 9:16). This highlights his sense of divine obligation, similar to Jeremiah 20:9 where the prophet cannot hold back the word of the Lord, and echoes Jesus’ Great Commission (Matthew 28:19-20).

questions.question: How does Paul describe his approach to those under the law and those without law in 1 Corinthians 9?
options: He becomes as one under the law to gain those under the law, and as one without law to gain those without law
He imposes the law on everyone
questions.correctAnswer: He becomes as one under the law to gain those under the law, and as one without law to gain those without law
questions.explanation: Paul explains his method of contextualization: becoming 'as under the law' to gain those under the law, and 'as without law' to reach those without law, that he might save some (1 Corinthians 9:20-21). This reflects his missionary strategy seen in Acts 17:22-34 and aligns with the incarnational model of ministry (Philippians 2:5-8).

questions.question: What does Paul mean when he says, 'I am made all things to all men' in 1 Corinthians 9:22?
options: He adapts himself to different people to save some
questions.correctAnswer: He adapts himself to different people to save some
questions.explanation: Paul’s statement that he becomes 'all things to all men' means he adapts his approach to different cultural and social contexts in order to win some to Christ (1 Corinthians 9:22). This does not mean compromising the gospel but practicing flexibility in expression, as seen in Acts 21:37-40 and 1 Corinthians 10:32.

questions.question: What is the ultimate reason Paul disciplines his body and brings it into subjection according to 1 Corinthians 9:27?
options: Lest after preaching to others he himself should be disqualified
questions.correctAnswer: Lest after preaching to others he himself should be disqualified
questions.explanation: Paul disciplines his body to avoid being disqualified or rejected after preaching to others (1 Corinthians 9:27). This metaphor emphasizes the importance of perseverance and holiness in the Christian life, consistent with Hebrews 12:1-2 and 2 Timothy 4:7.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 9:24-25, how is the Christian life compared to a race?
options: One must run to obtain the incorruptible crown with self-control
It is a race with no clear winner
questions.correctAnswer: One must run to obtain the incorruptible crown with self-control
questions.explanation: Paul compares the Christian life to a race where all run but only one receives the prize, urging believers to run so as to obtain the incorruptible crown with temperance (1 Corinthians 9:24-25). This echoes Hebrews 12:1-2 and 2 Timothy 2:5 which use athletic metaphors for Christian perseverance and discipline.

questions.question: What does Paul say is his reward for preaching the gospel willingly in 1 Corinthians 9:17-18?
options: To preach the gospel without charge and not abuse his power
To be honored by the church
questions.correctAnswer: To preach the gospel without charge and not abuse his power
questions.explanation: Paul states that if he preaches willingly, he receives a reward which is the ability to preach the gospel free of charge and avoid abusing his authority (1 Corinthians 9:17-18). This highlights his commitment to integrity and aligns with Jesus’ teaching about servant leadership (Mark 10:42-45).

questions.question: Who does Paul identify as living from the things of the temple and sharing with the altar in 1 Corinthians 9:13?
options: Those that minister about holy things and those who wait at the altar
questions.correctAnswer: Those that minister about holy things and those who wait at the altar
questions.explanation: Paul refers to those ministering in holy duties and waiting at the altar as living from the temple offerings and sharing with the altar (1 Corinthians 9:13), reflecting the Old Testament priestly system (Leviticus 7:28-36, Numbers 18:8-32) where temple workers received material provision.

questions.question: What is Paul’s attitude toward boasting about his ministry as expressed in 1 Corinthians 9:15-16?
options: He refuses to boast because preaching is a necessary duty
He boasts about his social status
questions.correctAnswer: He refuses to boast because preaching is a necessary duty
questions.explanation: Paul states he does not boast because preaching the gospel is a necessity laid upon him, and he would be wretched if he did not preach (1 Corinthians 9:15-16). This humility is consistent with Jesus’ teaching on servant leadership (Matthew 23:11) and Paul’s example in 2 Corinthians 12:7-10.
